They can persist in the UI, or they can be dismissed by the user. Alert Types In the Appwrite console, we use two types of alerts: Class Type alert Inline Inline alerts present additional information to the user related to content within a form or a body of text. alert-sticky Sticky Sticky alerts are used to notify the user about a change in the system status, or about a recently performed action. States In the Appwrite console, we use five states of alerts: Class Type - Default Use this alert to provide general information to the user. is-info Info Use this alert to provide additional information or ‘tips’ to the user. is-success Success Use this alert to inform the user of a task that has been completed successfully. is-warning Warning Use this alert to warn the user that action may be required depending on the context. is-danger Danger/Error Use this alert to warn the user about errors, and how they can fix the problem. 3.title: components - button
3.content: No results found Ctrl + K GitHub Ctrl + K GitHub Home Getting Started Foundations border radius colors elevation icons typography Utility box model colors display position reset responsive text theme visibility Layout container navigation pagination Components alerts avatar box button card code panel collapsible drop list file preview grid item input fields list loader modal output secondary tabs selectors status tables tabs tags tooltip uploader user profile components button Button Buttons Buttons are used to initialize an action. Button labels express what action will occur when the user interacts with it. Types In the Appwrite console, we use four types of buttons: Class Type - Primary We recommend you use primary buttons for the principal call to action in a page or screen. is-secondary Secondary Secondary buttons can be used in conjunction with a primary button. As part of a pair with primary button, a secondary button will often perform a negative action, such as ‘Cancel’. is-text Text Text buttons can be used to complete an action inside another component. is-only-icon Icon Icon button with rounded corners Preview HTML Hello world Hello world Hello world Hello world Hello world Hello world "> < button class = " button " > < span class = " text " > Hello world </ span > </ button > < button class = " button is-secondary " > < span class = " text " > Hello world </ span > </ button > < button class = " button is-text " > < span class = " text " > Hello world </ span > </ button > < button class = " button is-only-icon " aria-label = " Add new item " > < span class = " icon-plus " aria-hidden = " true " > </ span > </ button > Sizes There are two sizes of buttons; large and medium. Each size has its own purpose, so make sure you use every size correctly. class Type - Medium The most commonly used size (default size). Our input fields also have a 40px height, which is why we use medium size next to input fields. is-big Large Use in a case of call to action that should stand out and have a lot of attention, mostly used on landing pages. Preview HTML Hello world Hello world Hello world Hello world "> < button class = " button " > < span class = " text " > Hello world </ span > </ button > < button class = " button is-big " > < span class = " text " > Hello world </ span > </ button > Buttons With Icons We recommend using icons in cases where they have strong universal meaning and aid in the recognition of a button. In Appwrite, the icon is placed on the left by default. 4.title: components - card
4.content: No results found Ctrl + K GitHub Ctrl + K GitHub Home Getting Started Foundations border radius colors elevation icons typography Utility box model colors display position reset responsive text theme visibility Layout container navigation pagination Components alerts avatar box button card code panel collapsible drop list file preview grid item input fields list loader modal output secondary tabs selectors status tables tabs tags tooltip uploader user profile components card Card card Cards are used to group related content in a single container. This can include text, images, lists, buttons, and other elements. Styles In the Appwrite console, we use two styles of cards borders: Class Type - Solid Solid border should be use in all cards. is-border-dashed Dashed We recommend you use dash border for empty state cards. Preview HTML "> < article class = " card " style = " width : 300px ; height : 100px ; " > </ article > < article class = " card is-border-dashed " style = " width : 300px ; height : 100px ; " > </ article > Usage In Appwrite we are using cards to show empty states, to update / delete objects, to display overview, etc. A card can include avatars, buttons, illustrations, lists, tags and text for example: Create your first file to get started. 16.title: components - selectors
16.content: No results found Ctrl + K GitHub Ctrl + K GitHub Home Getting Started Foundations border radius colors elevation icons typography Utility box model colors display position reset responsive text theme visibility Layout container navigation pagination Components alerts avatar box button card code panel collapsible drop list file preview grid item input fields list loader modal output secondary tabs selectors status tables tabs tags tooltip uploader user profile components selectors Selectors Choice selectors allow users to complete tasks which involve making choices such as selecting options, switching settings on or off, or adding or removing items. Variants In the Appwrite console, we use three variants of choice selectors. Class Type Description - Checkbox Checkboxes allow users to select one or more items from a set. switch Checkbox Switches are used to quickly toggle between two possible states. They are commonly used for “on/off” switches. - Radio Radio buttons allow users to select one item from a set. Checkbox Checkboxes allow users to select one or more items from a set. Preview HTML "> < input type = " checkbox " /> < input type = " checkbox " checked = " true " /> States Attribute Type Description disabled Disabled Shown when clicking on a selector is not allowed. Preview HTML "> < input type = " checkbox " disabled /> < input type = " checkbox " checked = " true " disabled /> Sizes There are three sizes of selectors; large, medium and small. Preview HTML "> < input type = " radio " name = " radio-2 " disabled /> < input type = " radio " name = " radio-2 " checked = " true " disabled /> Size There are three sizes of selectors; large, medium and small. Each size has its own purpose, so make sure you use every size correctly. class Type Description is-small Small - Medium is-large Large Preview HTML "> < div class = " u-flex u-gap-16 u-main-center u-cross-center " > < input type = " radio " class = " is-small " name = " size " /> < input type = " radio " name = " size " checked = " true " /> < input type = " radio " class = " is-large " name = " size " /> </ div > Usage We recommend choice selectors next to labels should have at minimum 8px of space in between for legibility. Choice selectors should be aligned to the center of a single line of text. If there are multiple lines in a label should be aligned to the center of the first line in the label. Checkboxes allow users to select multiple items from a set. Do Use checkboxes to allow users select one or more options from a list with related items. Don't Do not use switches, they don’t imply the items are related, and take up more visual space. Switches and radio buttons refer to a single item. Radio buttons allow selecting only one item from a list, while switches allow turning an item on or off. Do If each item in a set can be independently controlled, use switches to allow on or off options. Don't Do not use radio buttons to allow on or off options. secondary tabs status Terms Privacy ⓒ 2023 Appwrite. All rights reserved.

Components Tabs consist of four components: Class Type tabs-list List - tabs-item Item - tabs-button Button - tabs-button-scroll Scroll Used when there is not enough space to display all tabs, mostly on mobile devices. The tabs-button-scroll element can be hidden by adding u-hide class to it. This maintains an uncluttered UI and reduces cognitive load for users. If more than six tabs are needed, and you can’t use another patterns in order to keep consistency, we recommend that you add a horizontal scrolling element to the tab navigation. The right arrow should always be visible. If the user can scroll right, the arrow is active, otherwise the arrow should be disabled. The left arrow should only visible if the user can scroll left. tables tags Terms Privacy ⓒ 2023 Appwrite. All rights reserved.

20.content: No results found Ctrl + K GitHub Ctrl + K GitHub Home Getting Started Foundations border radius colors elevation icons typography Utility box model colors display position reset responsive text theme visibility Layout container navigation pagination Components alerts avatar box button card code panel collapsible drop list file preview grid item input fields list loader modal output secondary tabs selectors status tables tabs tags tooltip uploader user profile components tags Tags tags Tags help organize and differentiate between different categories of content. In the Appwrite console, tags may be interactive or static (informative). Informative Informative tags are used to visually label information for easy understanding and/or navigation. In the Appwrite console, we use our system colours for each type of tag (gray, blue, green, orange, red) depending on context. Class Type - Default Use this tag to provide general details to the user. In the Appwrite console this style is typically used for ‘disabled’ state tags. is-info Info Use this tag to provide additional information or ‘tips’ to the user. is-success Success Use this tag to inform the user of a task that has been completed or verified successfully. is-warning Warning Use this tag to warn the user that action may be required, or a task is currently processing, depending on the context. is-danger Danger / Error Use this tag to warn the user about an error that may have occured or a task that failed. Preview HTML default info success warning error default info success warning error "> < div class = " tag " > < span class = " icon-info " aria-hidden = " true " > </ span > < span class = " text " > default </ span > </ div > < div class = " tag is-info " > < span class = " icon-info " aria-hidden = " true " > </ span > < span class = " text " > info </ span > </ div > < div class = " tag is-success " > < span class = " icon-check-circle " aria-hidden = " true " > </ span > < span class = " text " > success </ span > </ div > < div class = " tag is-warning " > < span class = " icon-exclamation " aria-hidden = " true " > </ span > < span class = " text " > warning </ span > </ div > < div class = " tag is-danger " > < span class = " icon-exclamation-circle " aria-hidden = " true " > </ span > < span class = " text " > error </ span > </ div > Usage We recommend the use of icons within informative tags only when necessary to convey context. Do Keep tag text short and simple so as not to distract the user who may be scanning for information. Don't If you choose to use icons, don’t mix and match their placement. Interactive Clickable or tappable tags. In the Appwrite console these are typically used to allow users to copy or edit an element’s ID. Use an icon to clarify the action (e.g. the ‘duplicate’ icon for copy and ‘pencil’ icon for edit). 24.title: foundations - border radius
24.content: No results found Ctrl + K GitHub Ctrl + K GitHub Home Getting Started Foundations border radius colors elevation icons typography Utility box model colors display position reset responsive text theme visibility Layout container navigation pagination Components alerts avatar box button card code panel collapsible drop list file preview grid item input fields list loader modal output secondary tabs selectors status tables tabs tags tooltip uploader user profile foundations border radius Border Radius Different sizes of border radius are used throughout the Appwrite UI according to the component size. Sizes In Appwrite console we use 4 sizes of border radius: Variable Value --border-radius-xsmall 4px Designed to soften the corners of small components, such as checkboxes, input fields, buttons, alerts and tooltips. Preview HTML "> < div class = " card " style = " border-radius : var ( --border-radius-xsmall ) ; width : 200px ; aspect-ratio : 1 / 1 ; " > </ div > Variable Value --border-radius-small 8px Designed to soften the corners of small components that are part of a bigger one or for medium components, such as items in the sidebar menu and popovers. Preview HTML "> < div class = " card " style = " border-radius : var ( --border-radius-small ) ; width : 200px ; aspect-ratio : 1 / 1 ; " > </ div > Variable Value --border-radius-medium 16px Used when a UI element is large or needs to float above the underlying UI, such as cards, modals and tables. Preview HTML "> < div class = " card " style = " border-radius : var ( --border-radius-medium ) ; width : 200px ; aspect-ratio : 1 / 1 ; " > </ div > Variable Value --border-radius-circular 50% Used only on specific elements that needs to be rounded, such as icon buttons, avatars, tags and switches. Preview HTML "> < div class = " card " style = " border-radius : var ( --border-radius-circular ) ; width : 200px ; aspect-ratio : 1 / 1 ; " > </ div > Usage Do Use large corner radius for big surface. Don't Use small corner radius for big surface, it will make it look really sharp and serious. user profile colors Terms Privacy ⓒ 2023 Appwrite. All rights reserved.

All shades we are using were selected while maintaining AA accessibility level. Brand Our expanded brand color palette contains 3 shades. This is our primary color palette used for primary actions. - -color-primary-100 - -color-primary-200 - -color-primary-300 Neutrals We are using our neutral palette for both light and dark modes. Neutrals used mostly for backgrounds, text, separators etc. - -color-neutral-0 - -color-neutral-5 - -color-neutral-10 - -color-neutral-30 - -color-neutral-50 - -color-neutral-70 - -color-neutral-100 - -color-neutral-120 - -color-neutral-150 - -color-neutral-200 - -color-neutral-300 - -color-neutral-400 - -color-neutral-500 System Colors In the Appwrite console, we use 4 system colors: Type Information Blue often used for informative alerts and ‘selected’ mode in choice selectors. Success Green often used for success alerts. Warning Orange often used for warning alerts and modals. Error Red often used for danger/error alerts. Information - -color-information-10 - -color-information-50 - -color-information-100 - -color-information-120 - -color-information-200 Success - -color-success-10 - -color-success-50 - -color-success-100 - -color-success-120 - -color-success-200 Warning - -color-warning-10 - -color-warning-50 - -color-warning-100 - -color-warning-120 - -color-warning-200 Danger - -color-danger-10 - -color-danger-50 - -color-danger-100 - -color-danger-120 - -color-danger-200 Additional Colors In the Appwrite console, we use the colors below in specific components, such as avatars. Blue - -color-blue-100 Green - -color-green-100 Orange - -color-orange-100 Red - -color-red-100 Purple - -color-purple-100 Pink - -color-pink-100 Special Colors Color Text - -color-text-disabled - -color-text-info - -color-text-danger - -color-text-warning - -color-text-success Common Border Color - -color-border border radius elevation Terms Privacy ⓒ 2023 Appwrite. 26.title: foundations - elevation
26.content: No results found Ctrl + K GitHub Ctrl + K GitHub Home Getting Started Foundations border radius colors elevation icons typography Utility box model colors display position reset responsive text theme visibility Layout container navigation pagination Components alerts avatar box button card code panel collapsible drop list file preview grid item input fields list loader modal output secondary tabs selectors status tables tabs tags tooltip uploader user profile foundations elevation Elevation Elevation is the relative distance between two surfaces along the z-axis. Shadows and blurs create a layered effect that visually indicates that an object is "elevated" in priority or hierarchy. Types In the Appwrite console we use two types of elevation: Class Type shadow-small Small Use to show contrast between layout elements, such as cards or tables, to the surface. shadow-large Large Use to show contrast between ‘floating’ components, such as popovers, alerts or modals, to the surface below. Preview HTML shadow-small shadow-large shadow-small shadow-large "> < div class = " card " style = " box-shadow : var ( --shadow-small ) ; " > < p class = " text u-margin-block-start-8 " > shadow-small </ p > </ div > < div class = " card " style = " box-shadow : var ( --shadow-large ) ; " > < p class = " text u-margin-block-start-8 " > shadow-large </ p > </ div > Usage Small shadows should be used with standard layout components (e.g. cards, tables). We recommend the use of a large drop-shadow for floating components (e.g. popovers, alerts, modals). Do To create contrast between a floating surface and the surface beneath, use shadow-large. Don't Do not make floating elements look flat by not using shadows. colors icons Terms Privacy ⓒ 2023 Appwrite. All rights reserved.

27.title: foundations - icons
27.content: No results found Ctrl + K GitHub Ctrl + K GitHub Home Getting Started Foundations border radius colors elevation icons typography Utility box model colors display position reset responsive text theme visibility Layout container navigation pagination Components alerts avatar box button card code panel collapsible drop list file preview grid item input fields list loader modal output secondary tabs selectors status tables tabs tags tooltip uploader user profile foundations icons Icons An icon is a visual representation of a command, device, directory, or common action. In Appwrite we use heroicons solid icons library. We recommend the use of up to three icon sizes for consistency. In the Appwrite console, for example, icons are either 24px, 20px (the default), or 16px. Icon size should depend on the height of the label the icon is next to, or if it’s next to a label at all. Usage We recommend icons next to labels should have at minimum 4px of space in between for legibility. Icons should be aligned to the center of a single line of text. If there are multiple lines in a label should be aligned to the center of the first line in the label. Do Use minimum 4px of space between icon to text and make sure they are centered. Don't Do not use less than 4px of space. If there are multiple lines in a label, do not center the icon to all of them, but to the first line. elevation typography Terms Privacy ⓒ 2023 Appwrite. All rights reserved.

29.title: getting started
29.content: No results found Ctrl + K GitHub Ctrl + K GitHub Home Getting Started Foundations border radius colors elevation icons typography Utility box model colors display position reset responsive text theme visibility Layout container navigation pagination Components alerts avatar box button card code panel collapsible drop list file preview grid item input fields list loader modal output secondary tabs selectors status tables tabs tags tooltip uploader user profile getting started Getting Started Pink Design, is the Appwrite open-source design system for building consistent and reusable user interfaces. To learn how to use the library, follow the steps below. CSS File Before we Start Make sure you have a project set up where you want to use the CSS library. Include the CSS library in your project copy the next code to the <head> section of your HTML file. "> < link rel = " stylesheet " href = " path/to/css/library.css " > Once you have included the CSS library in your project, you can start using its styles in your HTML elements. Javascript Before we Start Make sure you have npm installed on your computer. If you don’t have it already, you can download and install it from the npm website. Initialize your project Navigate to your project directory in your terminal or command prompt. In the project directory, paste the next command. npm init Create a json file Create a package.json file. This file will store information about your project, including the dependencies you install. Install the CSS library After initializing your project, copy the next command to install the CSS library. npm install @aw-labs/ui Include the library in your project After downloading the library, it should be added to your project’s node_modules directory. Now you can include the library in your project by importing it in your JavaScript files. import "@aw-labs/ui/dist/pinkui.css" ; Alternatively, you can add a link to the CSS file in the <head> section of your HTML file, similar to how you would do it without using npm: "> < link rel = " stylesheet " href = " node_modules/@aw-labs/ui/dist/pinkui.css " > Terms Privacy ⓒ 2023 Appwrite. All rights reserved.
